Graphical abstract Highlights ► Catalytic activity of support decreased in the order of SAPO-11>Al2O3 >Al-SBA-15. ► Catalytic activity of metal decreased in the order of Pt>Pd>Ni>Ru. ► High performance of SAPO-11 support was due to its weak acids and shape selectivity. Several Pt catalysts with various solid acid supports (SAPO-11, Al-SBA-15, and Al2O3) and various SAPO-11 supported active metal (Pd, Ni, Ru, Pt) catalysts were prepared and characterized using BET, XRD, XRF, CO pulse adsorption, and NH3-TPD techniques. Their catalytic performances in isomerization of hydrodeoxygenated jatropha oil were carried out using a fixed bed flow reactor system. All Pt/SAPO-11, Pt/Al-SBA-15, and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts showed high catalytic activity for isomerization of n-alkanes with long carbon chain. Especially over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst, a high yield of iso-C10–18 up to 79.4% was obtained, which was attributed to the absence of strong acidic sites of Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst. With an increase in reaction temperature, Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst still showed a high ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18, presumably because of its ordered microporous structure, which suppresses formation of multibranched product. The catalytic activity of SAPO-11 catalysts containing various active metals decreased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11>Pd/SAPO-11>Ni/SAPO-11>Ru/SAPO-11, which might be attributable to the difference of hydrogenation–dehydrogenation activity of these metals. Keywords Jatropha oil Isomerization n-Alkanes Platinum catalyst SAPO-11 1 Introduction Hydrotreatment of vegetable oils to produce green paraffinic products has attracted great attention as an excellent route to producing renewable transport fuels [1,2]. Many researchers have investigated the hydrotreatment of vegetable oils such as palm oil [3], rapeseed oil [4–7], sunflower oil [8,9], and jatropha oil [10–12] over conventionally used hydrodesulfurization catalysts such as sulfided NiMo/Al2O3, CoMo/Al2O3, and NiW/Al2O3. Results show that complete conversion of vegetable oils to hydrocarbons is attainable in suitable conditions and that liquid hydrocarbon products of these processes have high cetane numbers over 98. Nevertheless, these liquid hydrocarbon products consisted mainly of n-alkanes of C15–C18. Their cold flow properties are quite unfavorable (cloud point: 15–21°C), which strictly limits their application. To resolve cold flow property problems, isomerization of n-alkanes to their branched isomers is regarded as a feasible and promising method [12]. Isomerization of n-alkanes has been investigated intensely in the petroleum industry to increase the octane number of gasoline and to improve cold flow properties of diesel and lubricating oils [13–17]. Reports of those studies describe that bifunctional catalysts, which contain an acid function provided by supports and a metallic function provided by the metallic component, are regarded as effective and environmentally friendly. The acidity of the support plays a key role in the isomerization of n-alkanes, but also leads to a hydrocracking reaction, which is the main side reaction in the isomerization of n-alkanes. Cracking reactions should be limited strictly because of their production of undesired gas products, which cause the loss of liquid product yield and which generate carbon deposition leading to inactivation. Consequently, catalysts with high isomerization versus cracking activity are highly desirable. The isomerization/cracking ratio is believed to depend on factors such as the acid center strength, the acid center density, the metal type, the support pore size, and reaction conditions, in which the acid center strength and the acid center density were considered to be more important. An appropriate balance of these parameters is crucial for catalyst activity [15]. Catalysts with high hydrogenation activity and low acidity are regarded as the best choices for maximizing isomerization versus hydrocracking [18,19]. It is generally accepted that isomerization of n-alkanes on a bifunctional catalyst proceeds through a bifunctional mechanism [20–24]. Scheme 1 shows the main pathways of isomerization of n-alkane. First, n-alkane generates the n-carbenium ion via dehydrogenation at a metallic site and protonation at an acid site. The resultant n-carbenium ion consecutively generates monobranched carbenium ion and multibranched carbenium ion through skeletal rearrangement. Finally, the newly formed branched carbenium ion reacts with reactant alkanes/hydrogen, thereby yielding the iso-alkane molecule and another n-carbenium ion/proton. The carbenium ions might also generate smaller alkylcarbenium ions and alkenes through cracking reactions. On the one hand, although numerous studies have described n-alkanes isomerization, they have been focused on investigation of n-alkanes with short carbon chain such as C4–C6 hydrocarbons. Isomerization of diesel and lubricating oils has also been investigated by some researchers, but the feedstocks in these researches derive from petroleum resources and only contain n-alkanes to a very limited degree. On the other hand, according to the explanation provided above, the properties of support and active metals strongly affect the catalyst isomerization performance. Consequently, in this paper, Pt catalysts containing various supports with different acid properties and structure (SAPO-11, Al-SBA-15, and Al2O3) and SAPO-11 supporting various active metal (Pd, Ni, Ru and Pt) catalysts were prepared. They were characterized using BET, XRD, XRF, CO pulse adsorption, and NH3-TPD methods. Furthermore, we tested their catalytic performance for isomerization of hydrodeoxygenated jatropha oil which contained about 95% of n-alkanes with long carbon chain and investigated the effects of acidic properties and structure of the support and active metal. 2 Experimental 2.1 Feedstock The feedstock (HDO-oil) used for catalyst activity evaluation was produced by hydrotreatment of jatropha oil over a NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst. Details of the production were described in an earlier report [12]. Some physical and chemical properties of jatropha oil and HDO-oil were determined. The results are presented in Table 1 . Density and dynamic viscosity were determined using a hydrometer (JIS-II) and a dynamic viscometer (SV-10A; Vibro). The acid value, cloud point, and cetane index were determined respectively according to ASTM-D974, ASTM-D5773, and ASTM-D4737. Fatty acids found mainly in jatropha oil were palmitoleic, linoleic, oleic, palmitic, and stearic acids, of which the respective shares were 0.9%, 13.6%, 36.2%, 43.4%, and 5.9%. The HDO-oil composition was the following: n-C4–14, 1.6%; n-C15, 4.8%; n-C16, 10. 4%; n-C17, 25.7%; n-C18, 51.3%; iso-C4–18, 4.2%; C18+, 2.0%. 2.2 Catalysts SAPO-11 was synthesized hydrothermally according to a procedure reported earlier [25] as the following. 20.84g aluminum isopropoxide (97%) was mixed with 11.53g phosphoric acid (85%) and 48.77g distilled water and stirred in a beaker for 4h. Then 7.59g the mixture of di-n-propylamine and di-iso-propylamine in the molar ratio of 2 were added to the beaker. Subsequently, 1.39g silica gel was added to the beaker and the mixture was stirred thoroughly for 2h. Finally, the sol was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, then sealed and heated at 200°C for 24h without stirring. The molar composition of the synthesis gels was 1.0P2O5:1.0Al2O3:0.2SiO2:1.5R:60H2O, where R stands for the template mixture. The as-synthesized SAPO-11 sample was washed, filtrated, dried at 120°C for 2h and then calcined at 550°C for 4h in air flow. Al-SBA-15 was synthesized according to a previously published method [26]. 3.53g aluminum isopropoxide, 60g distilled water, 18g TEOS, and the required amount of hydrochloric acid were mixed and stirred at 35°C. After a clear solution was obtained, 8g Pluronic P123 was added. The mixture was stirred for another three days at 35°C. The molar composition of the synthesis gels was 1TEOS:0.1Al2O3:0.016P123:0.2HCl:127H2O. Hydrothermal treatment was conducted in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 100°C for 24h. The as-synthesized Al-SBA-15 sample was washed, filtrated, dried at 80°C for 12h, and then calcined in air flow at 550°C for 6h with a heating rate of 2.5°C/min. Al2O3 was a commercial support supplied by Nippon Ketjen Co. Ltd. The three supports were prepared according to the following procedure: First, 9g SAPO-11(or Al-SBA-15, Al2O3) was milled into powder and put into a Teflon beaker. 1g alumina sol and a small amount of deionized water were put into the Teflon beaker, with subsequent intensive stirring to produce a mud-like solid. The mud-like solid was pressed and shaped into small cylinders with an experimental scale model. Finally, the small cylinders were dried at room temperature for 12h and calcined in a muffle furnace at 550°C for 3h. All supports were crushed and sieved to 20–80mesh particle size. All catalysts were prepared following conventional impregnation method procedures as reported [27]. The respective supports were loaded with Pt, Pd, Ru, and Ni with aqueous solutions of H2PtCl6·6H2O, PdCl2, RuCl3·nH2O, and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, respectively, to achieve a loading amount of 0.03mmol/g. After impregnation, samples were dried at 105°C for 2h and then calcined at 450°C for 10h under air flow. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The XRD patterns were recorded using an X-ray diffractometer (RAD-IIC; Rigaku Corp.) with Cu–Ka radiation. Elemental analysis was conducted using an X-ray fluorescence instrument (EDX-800; Shimadzu Corp.). The samples were pressed into disks before analysis. Specific surface areas and pore sizes were ascertained from nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms recorded at −196°C (Belsorp-mini II; Bel Japan Inc.). Before measurements, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 400°C for 1h. The specific surface areas and pore volumes were calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Then, the pore size distribution was obtained from the desorption isotherm using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method and Micropore Analysis (MP) method. Then NH3-TPD experiments were conducted using a chemisorption–physisorption analyzer (ChemBET PULSAR TPR/TPD; Quantachrome Instruments) according to the following procedure. First, about 200mg of sample was put into the sample cell and pretreated at 400°C under hydrogen for 3h at 15mL/min. Subsequently, the sample was pretreated at 500°C under helium flow for 3h at 15mL/min. Furthermore, after cooling to 100°C, ammonia adsorption was conducted for 40min under ammonia flow at 15mL/min. The physically adsorbed ammonia was removed with blowing helium at 100°C for 2h. Finally, NH3-TPD of the samples was conducted by increasing the cell temperature linearly from 100°C to 650°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min and a helium flow rate of 15mL/min. Chemisorption of carbon monoxide was also performed using the same equipment with NH3-TPD at 30°C to determine the dispersion of active metals. The calculation of metal dispersion based on the assumption that the CO adsorption on metal molecular was monolayer adsorption (adsorption ratio of CO/metal was 1:1). The experimental errors of metal dispersion results and NH3-TPD results were ±3% and ±0.5%, respectively. 2.4 Activity test of catalysts Details of this apparatus were described in an earlier report [28]. Briefly explained, the reactions were conducted with a fixed-bed flow microreactor (8mm i.d.). About 3mL of catalyst was loaded and sandwiched within quartz sand in the reactor. The feedstock was injected into the hydrogen stream using a high-pressure pump. The reaction was conducted at 275–475°C, 3MPa of total pressure, with liquid hourly space velocity (LSHV)=2h−1, and the H2/feed ratio of 1200 (v/v). Before reaction, all the catalysts were reduced in situ at 400°C and atmospheric pressure by a H2 flow at a rate of 50mL/min for 3h. The catalytic activity was measured after stabilization of the catalyst (to total time on stream was about 5h). No marked deactivation of the various catalysts was observed during 5h reaction in any experiment. Two gas chromatographs (GC-2025 and GC-14B; Shimadzu Corp.), each equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a commercially available column (DB-1, 0.25mm×60m), were used to analyze the hydrocarbons in the gaseous products and liquid products. A gas chromatograph mass spectrometer (GCMS-QP5050A; Shimadzu Corp.) equipped with the same capillary column (DB-1, 0.25mm×60m) was used to identify the reaction hydrocarbon product components. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Results of XRD showed that the calcined SAPO-11 sample possessed the AEL structure (Fig. 1a). The SAPO-11 sample exhibited a low background. No additional peak was observed, which indicated that this sample was free from impurities. The small-angle XRD pattern of calcined Al-SBA-15 sample is presented in Fig. 1b. Results revealed an XRD pattern with an intense diffraction peak at 2θ =0.84° and three other weak peaks at 2θ =1.50°, 2.00°, and 3.36°, which can be indexed respectively in a system of hexagonal symmetry as (100), (110), (200), and (210) diffraction planes. These results are consistent with previously reported results of Al-SBA-15 [29]. Textural properties derived from adsorption–desorption isotherms of nitrogen on the supports and calcined catalysts are presented in Table 2 . SAPO-11 based catalysts (Ni/SAPO-11, Ru/SAPO-11, Pd/SAPO-11, and Pt/SAPO-11) had similar specific surface areas, which varied from 141 to 162m2/g. Metal loading might block some pores, but various metals exhibited only a slight effect on the surface area. The Pt/Al2O3 catalyst had a specific surface area of 272m2/g and Pt/Al-SBA-15 catalyst had a specific surface area of 624m2/g. The pore size distributions of Pt catalysts, as derived from the desorption branch of N2 isotherms, are presented in Fig. 2 . The Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst showed a narrow pore size distribution centered at 0.6nm. For Pt/Al-SBA-15 catalyst, the pore size distribution showed two distinct peaks: one located at 1.2nm indicating the presence of small complementary pores, and a second one of 3.2nm representing ordered mesopores. The pore size distribution of Pt/Al2O3 catalyst revealed a broader peak with a maximum at 12.2nm. The final metal loadings of the catalysts are also presented in Table 2. Al catalysts had a similar loading amount that varied from 0.029 to 0.031mmol/g. The carbon monoxide chemisorption experiments showed the active metal dispersion of Pt/Al-SBA-15 catalyst to be 63% and the active metal dispersion of Pt/Al2O3 catalyst to be 57%, which are both higher than those of the SAPO-11 based catalysts (49–53) (Table 2). This result can be explained by the higher specific surface areas of Al-SBA-15 and the Al2O3 support. The surface acidity properties of all reduced catalysts were investigated using NH3-TPD. The NH3-TPD profiles of all catalysts are portrayed in Fig. 3 : all SAPO-11 based catalysts showed a similar distribution of acidic sites. Loading of various metals did not markedly alter the acidity, probably because the loaded amounts of metals were too low. Pt/Al-SBA-15 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts showed a different distribution of acidic sites with SAPO-11 based catalysts. To compare the acidity distribution among these catalysts, the NH3-TPD profiles were separated into two or three peaks by fitting curves with Gaussian functions (A typical profile of deconvolution about Pt/Al-SBA-15 is given in Fig. 3). These peaks were divided into three categories as 233–265°C, 316–343°C, and 431–435°C, which respectively represent weak, medium, and strong acidity. The amounts of desorbed ammonia for each type of acidic site were calculated. They are presented in Table 3 . The numbers of weak and medium acidic sites decreased in the same order: Pt/Al2O3 >Pt/Al-SBA-15>SAPO-11 based catalysts. However the number of strong acidic sites decreased in the different order of Pt/Al-SBA-15>Pt/Al2O3 ≫SAPO-11 based catalysts. Results show that the weak and medium acidic sites were the dominant acid sites in all catalysts. 3.2 Isomerization of HDO-oil over various Pt catalysts Isomerization of HDO-oil over various Pt-loaded support catalysts (Pt/SAPO-11, Pt/Al-SBA-15, Pt/Al2O3) was conducted under conditions of T =275–475°C, LHSV=2h−1, P =3.0MPa, and H2/oil=1200mL/mL. In this study, hydrocarbon products were determined under all hydrotreatment conditions by two GCs. All yields were defined based on the molar number of carbon. Because the HDO-oil was a mixture mainly containing n-C15–n-C18 (92.2%), it was difficult to calculate the conversion for each component because lighter alkanes might be formed from the cracking of heavier ones. Therefore, the conversion of n-C18, which accounted for 51.3% in feed and which was heavier than other main components (as shown in Table 1), was calculated and used to compare the performance of various catalysts. Fig. 4 shows the conversions of n-C18 versus reaction temperatures over three Pt catalysts. Results show that the catalytic activity decreased in the order of Pt/Al-SBA-15>Pt/SAPO-11>Pt/Al2O3. The conversion of n-C15–18 engenders the formation of iso-C15–18 as the main products, together with cracking compounds made up of shorter chain-length hydrocarbons of C1–14. From the perspective of diesel production, slight cracking converting n-C15–18 mainly to C10–14 can also improve the cold flow properties of HDO-oil. Therefore, the high-quality C10–18 fraction was chosen as the target product for investigation. Table 4 shows a distribution of various fractions in Feed (HDO-oil) and all hydrocarbon products over three Pt catalysts under different conditions. The HDO-oil was mainly in the C10–18 (97.1%) fraction. With increasing reaction temperature, the fractions of C1–4 and C5–9 on all catalysts increased, but the fractions of C10–18 and C18+ on all catalysts decreased because high temperatures can activate the acid function of these three catalysts to achieve higher cracking activity. Fig. 5a and b presents the contents of fraction C1–9, C10–18 and iso-C10–18 in products, respectively, as functions of reaction temperature. Content of fraction C10–18 over all catalysts decreased while content of fraction C1–9 increased with an increase in reaction temperature. Content of iso-C10–18 also increased with an increase in reaction temperature. This is because both isomerization and hydrocracking occurred via the carbenium ion mechanism on the acid, sites and higher temperature could activate the acid function of these catalysts to achieve a higher isomerization and cracking activity [12]. High contents of iso-C10–18 are obtainable over all three Pt catalysts. Especially, a high content of iso-C10–18 up to 79.4% was obtained over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst. Taking into account of the content of C10–18 (target fraction), when the content of C10–18 fraction is higher than 88%, the highest content of iso-C10–18 point over three catalysts decrease in the order of Pt/SAPO-11 (350°C, 79.4%)>Pt/Al2O3 (450°C, 56.7%)>Pt/Al-SBA-15(300°C, 43.7%). It is no doubt that Pt/SAPO-11 showed the best performance. Because the Pt loading amount was low (about 0.6wt%), there was no great difference in Pt dispersion of three Pt catalysts. Therefore, the Pt dispersion was not considered to be main reason for the difference of isomerization activity. Comparison with the NH3-TPD results (Table 3) shows that the difference of isomerization activity could be attributed to the fact that Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al-SBA-15 catalysts had strong acid sites which caused higher hydrocracking activity, but Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst had no such sites. Consequently, supports lacking strong acid sites were regarded as good choices for isomerization of long-chain n-alkanes. Among iso-C10–18 products, monobranched iso-C10–18 products were inferred to be the most desirable products because they not only improved the cold flow properties of HDO-oil but also maintained a high cetane number of the products. Fig. 5c shows the ratio of monobranched to multibranched iso-C10–18 as a function of the reaction temperature. Results show that monobranched iso-C10–18 was the dominant isomer product over all catalysts and the ratio of monobranched to multibranched iso-C10–18 decreased with the increase in reaction temperature. This is because isomerization of n-alkanes occurs through a series of consecutive reactions, as shown in Scheme 1, where the n-alkane is first isomerized into its monobranched isomers and subsequently into dibranched, and tribranched isomers, etc. A remarkable difference in contents of monobranched iso-C10–18 and multibranched iso-C10–18 was observed among the three Pt catalysts. With the increase in reaction temperature, the ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18 over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst decreased much slowly than the ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched over Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al-SBA-15 catalysts. The ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18 over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst at 375°C (conversion of n-C18: 99.1%) was still high up to ca. 2.9. This difference is attributable to the different textural properties of the three supports. As shown in Fig. 2, Pt/Al-SBA-15 (3.2nm) and Pt/Al2O3 (12.2nm) catalyst had much larger pores than Pt/SAPO-11. Consequently, the generation of multibranched iso-alkanes can be suppressed in the micropores over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst but it cannot be suppressed over Pt/Al-SBA-15 and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts because of the shape selectivity. SAPO-11 has medium pores (0.65nm×0.4nm) and a one-dimensional framework, as shown in Fig. 6 [30]. The critical diameters of n-alkanes and monobranched alkanes and germinal dibranched alkanes are nearly equal to 0.43–0.49, 0.50–0.62, and 0.7nm, respectively [15]. Consequently, n-alkanes and monobranched alkanes can diffuse in the micropores of SAPO-11, although the multibranched alkane diffusivity is suppressed. A scheme of shape selectivity for n-C18 isomerization over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst is shown as Scheme 2 . In ordered micropores of Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst, skeletal isomerization from n-alkane to monobranched iso-alkane (A) and the methyl-transfer reaction of monobranched iso-alkane (B) are the main reactions and proceeds. However, further generation of multibranched iso-alkanes from monobranched iso-alkanes is suppressed because of the limit of micropore size (C). In addition, a small part of isomerization from monobranched iso-alkanes to multibranched iso-alkanes (D) and hydrocracking from multibranched iso-alkanes (E) occurs in the outer surface of the catalyst. Some typical properties of liquid hydrocarbon products over the three Pt catalysts are presented in Table 5 . It was found that the low-temperature fluidity of the liquid hydrocarbon products was significantly improved after hydroisomerization. Meanwhile, these liquid hydrocarbon products still had high cetane indexes. Especially over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst, the liquid hydrocarbon products still had a high cetane index up to 84units and the cloud point was low down to −24°C. These liquid hydrocarbon products had suitable density and viscosity, high cetane index, good low-temperature fluidity and can serve as high-performance blend stocks of diesel oil. 3.3 Isomerization of HDO-oil over various SAPO-11 supported catalysts Isomerization of HDO-oil over various metal-loaded SAPO-11 catalysts (Pt/SAPO-11, Ni/SAPO-11, Ru/SAPO-11, Pd/SAPO-11) was conducted under conditions of T =300–375°C, LHSV=2h−1, P =3.0MPa, and H2/oil=1200mL/mL. Fig. 7 shows conversions of n-C18 versus reaction temperatures over four SAPO-11 based catalysts. The catalytic activity for hydroconversion of HDO-oil decreased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11>Pd/SAPO-11>Ni/SAPO-11>Ru/SAPO-11. The Ru/SAPO-11 catalyst had almost no hydroconversion activity. It was reported [31–33] that well dispersed Ru supported catalyst (small ruthenium clusters) possessed less activity on the hydroconversion of hydrocarbons. Therefore, the low reactivity of Ru/SAPO-11 could be attributed to that it had a low Ru loading and a relative high dispersion, resulting in extremely less active centers. Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst had low conversion, whereas Pt/SAPO-11 and Pd/SAPO-11 catalysts had high conversion. These results also illustrate that the metallic function is a crucial factor in isomerization catalysts. According to the previous description of the reaction mechanism (Scheme 1), generation of n-carbenium ion from n-alkane by dehydrogenation on a metallic site and protonation on an acid site starts the reaction. That is a crucial step. The different performances of various active metals can result from their hydrogenation capability. Because of its extremely low hydroconversion activity, Ru/SAPO-11 catalyst will not be described in the following discussion. Table 6 shows contents of various fractions in all products over four SAPO-11 based catalysts under various reaction temperatures. With increasing reaction temperature, the fractions of C1–4 and C5–9 on all catalysts increased, but the fractions of C10–18 and C18+ on all catalysts decreased because the cracking reaction occurred favorably at higher temperatures. Fig. 8a and b presents content of fraction C1–9, C10–18 and iso-C10–18 as functions of reaction temperature over various SAPO-11 based catalysts, respectively. Content of fraction C10–18 in all products over SAPO-11 based catalysts decreased while content of fraction C1–9 increased with an increase in reaction temperature. The content of fraction C10–18 decreased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11>Pd/SAPO-11>Ni/SAPO-11. The content of fraction C1–9 increased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11<Pd/SAPO-11<Ni/SAPO-11. These results implied that the hydrocracking activity increased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11<Pd/SAPO-11<Ni/SAPO-11. From Fig. 8b, it is apparent that the content of iso-C10–18 in products decreased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11>Pd/SAPO-11>Ni/SAPO-11. Isomerization of n-alkanes over bifunctional catalysts was widely recognized to progress through the carbenium ion mechanism. As show in Scheme 1, carbenium ions were formed through dehydrogenation on active metal sites and through the addition of protons on acid sites from alkanes. Generally, the hydrogenation–dehydrogenation activity was considered to decrease in the order of Pt>Pd>Ni. And it was also reported that Pt catalysts had higher activity in hydrogenation of benzene and hydrogen chemisorption ability than Pd and Ni catalysts [34,35]. Consequently, the high isomerization activity of Pt could be attributable to its high hydrogenation–dehydrogenation activity. Fig. 8c shows the ratio of monobranched to multibranched iso-C10–18 over SAPO-11 catalysts, loaded with various metals, as a function of reaction temperature. The ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18 over Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst did not decrease significantly with the increase of reaction temperature, which could be attributed to the content of iso-C10–18 was low at all reaction temperature. The ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18 over Pt/SAPO-11 and Pd/SAPO-11 catalysts decreased with an increase in reaction temperature. This is because the generated monobranched isomers isomerized into dibranched and tribranched isomers further. At high reaction temperature, Pt/SAPO-11 showed higher ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18 than Pd/SAPO-11 catalysts, which could be attributed to that Pt had higher hydrogenation activity and terminated the reaction of monobranched iso-C10–18 further generates multibranched iso-C10–18. 4 Conclusions Several Pt catalysts containing various solid acid supports (SAPO-11, Al-SBA-15 and Al2O3) and SAPO-11 catalysts containing various active metals (Pd, Ni, Ru and Pt) were prepared. The catalysts were characterized using several experimental techniques and were then tested for hydroconversion of hydrodeoxygenated jatropha oil. High conversions and high yields of iso-C10–18 products were achieved under suitable conditions over all three Pt catalysts. Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst showed the highest yield of iso-C10–18, which can be attributed to the absence of strong acidic sites of Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst. With an increase in reaction temperature, Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst still showed a high ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18, presumably attributable to its ordered microporous structure, which suppressed the formation of multibranched products. The respective catalytic activity of SAPO-11 catalysts containing various active metals decreased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11>Pd/SAPO-11>Ni/SAPO-11>Ru/SAPO-11. Pt/SAPO-11 and Pd/SAPO-11 catalysts showed superior performance to that of Ni/SAPO-11 and Ru/SAPO-11, which can be attributed to their high hydrogenation–dehydrogenation activity. References [1] T. coredata.dc:description: Several Pt catalysts with various solid acid supports (SAPO-11, Al-SBA-15, and Al2O3) and various SAPO-11 supported active metal (Pd, Ni, Ru, Pt) catalysts were prepared and characterized using BET, XRD, XRF, CO pulse adsorption, and NH3-TPD techniques. Their catalytic performances in isomerization of hydrodeoxygenated jatropha oil were carried out using a fixed bed flow reactor system. All Pt/SAPO-11, Pt/Al-SBA-15, and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts showed high catalytic activity for isomerization of n-alkanes with long carbon chain. Especially over Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst, a high yield of iso-C10–18 up to 79.4% was obtained, which was attributed to the absence of strong acidic sites of Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst. With an increase in reaction temperature, Pt/SAPO-11 catalyst still showed a high ratio of monobranched iso-C10–18 to multibranched iso-C10–18, presumably because of its ordered microporous structure, which suppresses formation of multibranched product. The catalytic activity of SAPO-11 catalysts containing various active metals decreased in the order of Pt/SAPO-11>Pd/SAPO-11>Ni/SAPO-11>Ru/SAPO-11, which might be attributable to the difference of hydrogenation–dehydrogenation activity of these metals.
coredata.dc:title: Isomerization of n-alkanes derived from jatropha oil over bifunctional catalysts
